said the following:

I think of it as the mathematics/logic of natural selection. Natural selection would be the biological view and game theory is more the mathematical view. 

So something like the simple phrase ‚Äúeat or be eaten‚Äù would be the natural view. And game theory would model those interactions with math.

Bitcoin pretty much runs on math and physics, outside the control of any human. So as time progresses, the way it interacts/operates in the world with us humans could be modeled/described through the lense of game theory because it is very predictable if you assume a long enough time frame.

And that‚Äôs why you‚Äôll hear people say certain things are inevitable. And you can only do that because it is fully decentralized and secured by proof of work. So it can‚Äôt be manipulated in ways that can‚Äôt be predicted.

Schelling point - In game theory, a focal point (or Schelling point) is a solution that people tend to choose by default in the absence of communication. 
More: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focal_point_(game_theory)

I'm not sure if a "first principles" mindset applies to game theory, but I'm putting this here for now. I stumbled upon this article which does a great job at explaining the methodology behind thinking in first principles and why it's valuable to creativity and ingenuity. There are lots of helpful metaphors including coaching sports, Elon Musk's successful career, and the difference between chefs and cooks. https://fs.blog/first-principles/

The "prisoner's dilemma" is an example of a non-zero-sum game, where the actions of each player could make their combined situation better without taking from each other. If neither confesses you both get a year for a crime, if you onfesses and the other doesn't, you get 0 years and the other gets 10 years. If you both confess, you both get 5 years in prison.

Game theory examples in real life (as outlined in The Price of Tomorrow book chapter 9)
Carpool lane (single occupant cars cheat to go faster, but when more and more do it everyone goes slower)
Doping in sports....bad for your health but athletes and teams think it's worth the risk to gain competitive advantage. Lance Armstrong ex.
Military spending - if no country invested in their military, that money can be used to benefit society. But if one chose to break the rule they get a big advantage.
Group dynamics: what might be better for one person often is worse for the group - ex. Currency manipulation

Capitalism is known as a dominant cooperative strategy that with the rise of fiat currencies and 2008 bailout eventually failed and led to crony capitalism where the cheaters (banks) were rewarded and won.
Game theory makes us cooperate or betray depending on the incentive or punishment.
